fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Realisability semantics of parametric polymorphism, general references and recursive types, Semantics of Types for Mutable State

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Most practical programming languages have side effects: state, input-output, errors, etc.
Monads capture the structure of side effects (Moggi, Wadler).
State means being able to interact with the computer’s memory; references or pointers govern access to a location in memory.
The syntax of state varies along three axes:

html:p.html:em: What kind of things can be stored in memory cells?
When can these memory cells be allocated?
What equations hold of stateful computations?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Storing only integers or other first-order data.
Models of very extensional equational theory including “garbage collection” found by Plotkin, Power; Staton. Adapted to “full ground store” (storage of pointers) by Kammar, Levy, Moss, and Staton.
Extensionality of models lost when moving to higher-order storage.
An extreme point in the design space...
Deeply impredicative: heap contains elements of arbitrary types.
\Longrightarrow guarded recursion (step-indexing) used to break the circularity.
An equational theory of higher-order store in which reads to the heap leave behind “breadcrumbs”.
Consider two implementations of an “counter” object:

html:p.html:em: What is the relationship between \mathsf {posCounter} and \mathsf {negCounter}?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: They appear to be indistinguishable. Indeed, they are “observationally equivalent”!

Observational equivalence is an extremely weak property: indistinguishability under observations of ground type only. It would be great if we could instead deduce an absolute equation: \color {red}\vdash \mathsf {posCounter} \equiv \mathsf {negCounter} \colon \mathsf {Counter} (No cheating: we want “standard” models without extensional collapse or logical relation.)
We add two additional rules to the equational theory of guarded higher-order dynamic allocation.

CELL UNIVALENCE. For f^+\colon A\to B and f^-\colon B\to A with x:B\vdash f^+{\mathopen {}\left (f^-{\mathopen {}\left (x\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}\equiv x and x\colon A\vdash f^-{\mathopen {}\left (f^+{\mathopen {}\left (x\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} \equiv x we have:
The theory of univalent reference types derives \vdash \mathsf {posCounter} \equiv \mathsf {negCounter}.
The function \mathsf {neg} \colon \mathsf {Integer}\to \mathsf {Integer} is inverse to itself; therefore, apply CELL UNIVALENCE with f^+ \equiv f^- \equiv \mathsf {neg} and simplify.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let’s start with the non-univalent fragment (“guarded higher-order dynamic allocation”).

fr:title.text: Models of guarded higher order dynamic allocation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Models of guarded higher order dynamic allocation

fr:mainmatter.html:p: S., Gratzer, and Birkedal (2022) found synthetic denotational semantics for guarded higher-order dynamic allocation in an impredicative version of guarded dependent type theory (iGDTT).
Guarded recursion needed to solve the domain equation; impredicativity needed to define the monad (b/c \mathsf {Heap} is large).

Our main observation is that a slight variation on SGB’22 suffices to model univalent reference types, so long as both \mathbf {FinSet} and \mathbf {Set} are both univalent universes in the sense of Voevodsky.

html:ol.html:li: Univalence of \mathbf {FinSet} implies the LAYOUT UNIVALENCE rule.
Univalence of \mathbf {Set} implies the CELL UNIVALENCE rule.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We therefore need an impredicative version of guarded homotopy type theory.
We define iGHoTT to be the extension of Martin-Löf’s intensional type theory by the following additional features:

html:ol.html:li: homotopy type theory: the univalence axiom
guarded recursion: later modality \mathord {\blacktriangleright } and solutions to guarded fixed points
a univalent impredicative universe, i.e. a universe \mathcal {S}\in \mathcal {U} closed under families of \mathcal {S}-small types indexed in a \mathcal {U}-small type.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In iGHoTT, we can define a model of univalent reference types. The real question is whether we can find a model of iGHoTT.
Palombi and S. (2023) have contributed a modular method for building models of (non-univalent) guarded dependent type theory over an arbitrary base topos. As applied by SGB’22:

html:ol.html:li: Any realisability topos \mathcal {E} contains an impredicative universe \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {E}}.

Then the relative presheaf topos \mathcal {F} :\equiv {\mathopen {}\left [\mathbb {O}^{\mathsf {op}},\mathcal {E}\right ]\mathclose {}} is a model of guarded recursion and contains an impredicative universe \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {F}} defined from \mathbb {M}_{\mathcal {E}} by Hofmann—Streicher lifting.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We have not gotten around to adapting the SGB’22 model of iGDTT to obtain a model of iGHoTT, which is much more complicated.

html:ol.html:li: Let \mathbb {A} be a partial combinatory algebra.
Let \square be a suitable internal cube category in \mathbf {PER}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}, and let \mathbb {O} be an internal well-founded order in the same.

Then the category of internal presheaves of assemblies {\mathopen {}\left [{\mathopen {}\left (\square \times \mathbb {O}\right )\mathclose {}}^{\mathsf {op}},\mathbf {Asm}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}\right ]\mathclose {}} is expected to form a model of iGHoTT{}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Impredicative HoTT via cubical assemblies due to Awodey et al. and studied by Uemura, Swan.
Guarded HoTT via \square \times \mathbb {O} due to Birkedal et al. (2019).

fr:title.text: A more canonical model of iGHoTT?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A more canonical model of iGHoTT?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Even if internal presheaves of assemblies on \square \times \mathbb {O} works, the resulting model will be uncanonical from the {\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-categorical standpoint.
For example, if \mathbb {O}=\omega , we shall not have defined the “internal (pre)-{\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-topos of trees” in cubical assemblies.

More canonical approach would be to take internal presheaves on any \mathcal {S}-small well-founded order \mathbb {O} internal to the {\mathopen {}\left (\infty ,1\right )\mathclose {}}-category \mathcal {E} presented by {\mathopen {}\left [\square ^{\mathsf {op}},\mathbf {Asm}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {A}\right )\mathclose {}}\right ]\mathclose {}}. This may introduce coherence problems that we are currently unprepared for.

fr:title.text: Comparing with other realisability models of state

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Comparing with other realisability models of state

fr:mainmatter.html:p: SGB’22 were not the first to combine guarded recursion with realisability to model higher-order dynamic allocation; see Birkedal, Støvring, and Thamsborg (2010).

However, op.cit. relied on a specific realisability model based on an untyped domain model of a stateful language; in contrast, the model construction of SGB’22 applies uniformly for any pair {\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {E},\mathbb {O}\right )\mathclose {}}.
Thus SGB’22 showed that realisability is inessential: if we find any other viable source of impredicative universes besides realisability, SGB’22 would apply there too.

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @inproceedings{sterling-gratzer-birkedal-2024-univalent, author = {Sterling, Jonathan and Gratzer, Daniel and Birkedal, Lars}, title = {{Towards Univalent Reference Types: The Impact of Univalence on Denotational Semantics}}, booktitle = {32nd EACSL Annual Conference on Computer Science Logic (CSL 2024)}, pages = {47:1--47:21}, series = {Leibniz International Proceedings in Informatics (LIPIcs)}, ISBN = {978-3-95977-310-2}, ISSN = {1868-8969}, year = {2024}, volume = {288}, editor = {Murano, Aniello and Silva, Alexandra}, publisher = {Schloss Dagstuhl -- Leibniz-Zentrum f{\"u}r Informatik}, address = {Dagstuhl, Germany}, doi = {10.4230/LIPIcs.CSL.2024.47}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We develop a denotational semantics for general reference types in an impredicative version of guarded homotopy type theory, an adaptation of synthetic guarded domain theory to Voevodsky’s univalent foundations. We observe for the first time the profound impact of univalence on the denotational semantics of mutable state. Univalence automatically ensures that all computations are invariant under symmetries of the heap—a bountiful source of program equivalences. In particular, even the most simplistic univalent model enjoys many new program equivalences that do not hold when the same constructions are carried out in the universes of traditional set-level (extensional) type theory.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A fundamental theme in automata theory is regular languages of words and trees, and their many equivalent definitions. Salvati has proposed a generalization to regular languages of simply typed λ-terms, defined using denotational semantics in finite sets.

We provide here some evidence for its robustness. First, we give an equivalent syntactic characterization that naturally extends the seminal work of Hillebrand and Kanellakis connecting regular languages of words and syntactic λ-definability. Second, we exhibit a class of categorical models of the simply typed λ-calculus, which we call finitely pointable, and we show that, when used in Salvati’s definition, they all recognize exactly the same class of languages of λ-terms as the category of finite sets does.

The proofs of these two results rely on logical relations and can be seen as instances of a more general construction of a categorical nature, inspired by previous categorical accounts of logical relations using the gluing construction.
